author: Terry Richardson
title: Visit the world's least crowded country - before everyone else does
text:
Visit the world's least crowded country - before everyone else does Two new luxury hotels and a new international airport are opening up Mongolia Terry Richardson , Destination expert  43am 
“Big Sky Country” is a fitting nickname for ruggedly beautiful Montana, the fourth largest US state. If the same sobriquet were applied to Mongolia, however, it would simply be inadequate. For this enormous landlocked country of green steppe, vast flat plains, intricately braided rivers, electric-blue highland lakes, snow-licked mountains, dense pine forests and shifting desert is presided over by a skyscape of such bold blue immensity it beggars description. 
It’s not just vast; Mongolia is empty, too. Three times bigger than France, its population is less than a 20th of the UK’s – and one in three people live in the nation’s sole city, the capital Ulaan Baatar. Mongolia is empty. Three times bigger than France, its population is less than a 20th of the UK’s 
It is also, even a quarter of a century after freeing itself from the shackles of Moscow, very little visited – something that is beginning to change, following the opening of two new luxury hotels in Ulaan Baatar and the scheduled opening this year of a new international airport. Mapped: The world's most (and least) crowded countries 
I decided to get in ahead of the crowds by taking a journey by 4x4 through this incredible land, so sparse in terms of people but, with more than three million horses, 28 million sheep, as many goats, nearly four million cattle and 200,000 Bactrian camels, so rich in terms of livestock. The conical felt tents that still house almost 50 per cent of Mongolia’s inhabitants Credit: Christopher Meder - Fotolia 
Hardly surprisingly, animal husbandry forms the backbone of the economy. I was invited into my first ger (the conical felt tents that still house almost 50 per cent of Mongolia’s inhabitants) a couple of days into my trip, heading south on dirt roads from the tiny settlement of Murun, in the north. Sitting on low couches, my guide Duggi, driver Tziggi and myself slurped on the bowls of warm, salted butter tea proffered by our host . Top 10 | The least crowded destinations on Earth 
I gazed around the ger with interest. Like all the best homes, the focal point was the fireplace, in this case a smoke-blackened iron stove. Above the wood-burner hung a line of ragged strips of beef being air-cured for jerky, while slices of curd dangled from strings above the door. Large aluminium trays contained yogurt and cheese, another yellow cream so thick our host sliced it with a knife before handing us a portion to try (it was delicious!). Meat and dairy produce form the average Mongolian’s staple diet; fruit and vegetables are a rarity. With the nearest shop a day and half’s journey away, these nomadic families rely on what they can produce themselves. 
Under flawlessly blue late-August skies, the temperatures a beatific 20C or so, and our host’s young daughter doing cartwheels, it was hard not to be enraptured. Especially as the valley below the ger was threaded by a tumbling brook and pine-carpeted peaks swept up all around. But it’s a harsh life, and that wood-burner would be needed, as the first snows usually fall in September, and midwinter temperatures drop to -40C. 17 unusual destinations where the terror threat is low 
The nomadic pastoralist way of life, still practised by almost 30 per cent of the population, forms a fascinating backdrop of any trip to Mongolia. From the lakes, mountains and forests of the north through the vast steppe-lands of the centre to the deserts of the Gobi in the south, you never seem to be very far from a ger camp. 
But there are some settlements too. Jargalan is an isolated example made up entirely of pine-built, pitched-roofed houses, each with its own fenced yard. There’s something of the Wild West about it. Rolling through town on the rutted dirt road, it’s easy to imagine yourself a settler heading west through a frontier township – especially when the local population look similar to many Native Americans (understandably, given that indigenous Americans originated in the area where modern Russia, Mongolia, China and Kazakhstan intersect). 
Rather bigger is the provincial town of Kharkhorin. This is the historical centre of the country. Here Genghis Khan (more properly Chinggis Khan) built Karakorum, the capital city of an empire which, in its 13th-century heyday, stretched from the Sea of Japan to Central Europe. Chinggis was hardly a pacifist, but his reputation for brutality is leavened by the fact that his capital was home to places of worship for Buddhists, Christians and Muslims. He remains a source of pride for all Mongolians, and statues of him dot the country. The largest, close to Ulaan Baatar, a 40m high behemoth, has earned a place in the Guinness Book of Records. Genghis Khan remains a source of pride for all Mongolians, and statues of him dot the country Credit: astreluk - Fotolia 
Little remains of Karakorum today, though a new museum gives some fascinating background. There are plenty of other historical sites around Kharkhorin – indeed the whole region has been designated the Orkhon Valley Cultural Landscape, a Unesco World Heritage Site. I visited the atmospheric remains of several cities left by successive empires in the region – the Göktürk, Uighur and Qitan – all of whom preceded the Mongol Empire. Today’s Turks, whose ancestors migrated westwards from here between the sixth and 10th centuries, revere this region, as a couple of stelae found here, today housed in a museum above the valley, are inscribed with the first Turkic language texts. Far older than the Turkic stelae are deer stones – Bronze Age megaliths carved with beautifully stylised deer and other motifs, standing between three and 15 feet high. I visited several deer stone sites, including one near Murun, and another north of Kharkhorin. Experts are divided on their purpose, but for the modern traveller these mysterious granite standing stones make a fantastic foreground for photographs of the boundless steppe on which they have been erected. 
Kharkhorin was also the starting point of my trip to Tovkhon Monastery, reached after an incredibly scenic three-hour drive up the upper reaches of the Orkhon river, and evocatively set on a limestone outcrop peeping out above a sea of pine trees. This was once the home of the 17th-century Buddhist monk Zanabazar, one of those who faith brought north from Tibet. He was a sculptor sometimes dubbed the “Michelangelo of Asia” whose exquisite statues of the Buddha and Bodhisattvas are the centrepieces of Ulaan Baatar’s excellent Zanabazar Museum of Fine Arts. But many were produced in this remote monastery. Today it’s a lovely spot, with nearby trees bedecked with lines of fluttering blue prayer flags, the entire forest ringing with bird song. A palace in Ulaan Baatar Credit: Christopher Meder - Fotolia 
One of the great joys of my trip was the sheer abundance of bird life. I saw buzzards, eagles, hawks and falcons, steppe vultures, alpine chough, crane, ruddy shelduck, wheatears and many more. Wildlife, vast herds of feral horses apart, was harder to spot. But one dusk, in the Hustai National Park, I was delighted to see marmots galore, a ridge outlined with the distinctive silhouettes of three red deer stags, and a herd of stocky Przewalski’s horses. The latter, reintroduced into its native environment after being made extinct in the wild, is the world’s only true wild horse. 
Towards the end of my trip, in true tourist fashion I took a short camel ride (and having now experienced both, I can assure you that Mongolia’s twin-humped Bactrian camels are far more comfortable and secure than single-humped dromedaries), and enjoyed a delightful walk up the Yolyn Am gorge, watching yellow wagtails flit alongside a burbling brook and lammergeiers wheel overhead. I also saw what I am sure was a gerbil, and more certainly identified another very cute rodent, the pika, numbers of which scurried and whistled warnings among the undergrowth. Mongolia’s twin-humped Bactrian camels are far more comfortable and secure than single-humped dromedaries Credit: twinsterphoto - Fotolia 
Then there was a fine stroll along the weirdly eroded Flaming Cliffs, where in the 1920s American adventurer Roy Chapman Andrews (the inspiration for Indiana Jones) found Central Asia’s first dinosaur eggs, and a hike up a rocky outcrop to find some rock carvings of deer and mounted warriors. 
Sitting high on that outcrop and gazing across that extraordinary landscape, I paused to reflect. When I was growing-up in 1970s Britain, Mongolia was byword for remoteness. It was the kind of place you almost certainly wouldn’t be able to locate on a map, let alone get to – it was then a Soviet satellite state. Yet on my visit to the country I had shared a flight with a group of ladies from the British Horse Society setting out on an equine adventure, met a bunch of middle-aged Frenchmen riding Indian-built Royal Enfield motorcycles, bumped into a Dutch father and daughter on a cycling jaunt, and conversed with a posse of burly American anglers on a wilderness fly-fishing trip in pursuit of the legendary taimen. 
Mongolia may still feel remote compared with many countries, but with the new hotels and airport it is opening up to tourism. The rewards for those who make the effort to get to this stunningly beautiful, unspoilt country are, like its sky, immense. Mongolia's big sky Credit: Dmitry Pichugin - Fotolia How to get there 
UK tour operators offering holidays to Mongolia include Regent Holidays (020 3553 0569; regent-holidays.co.uk ), which has an escorted eight-day “Highlights of Mongolia” taking in Ulaan Baatar, a journey through the Gobi Desert and a visit to Kharkhorin, from £1,470 excluding flights. 
Exodus (020 3131 6886; exodus.co.uk ) has three guided activity itineraries including a 15-day “Steppes, Deserts and Nomads” tour and a 16-day cycling holiday, both starting at £2,769 including flights. 
More luxurious, tailor-made itineraries are available from Steppes Travel (01285 601759; steppestravel.co.uk ) and include a nine-day “Yurt Camping and Fossil Hunting” from £5,295, with a half-day, horseback tour of Gun-Galuut Nature Reserve. 
G Adventures (0344 272 2080; gadventures.co.uk ) has a 15-day “Naadam Festival Mongolia” in July to coincide with Ulaan Baatar’s festival programme of horse racing and archery, at £1,899 excluding flights. The festival (July 9-16 2017, naadamfestival.com ) is one of the best times to visit with wrestling, archery and horse-riding competitions. Otherwise the summer months of May-September are sunny and warm; the rest of the year is either chilly or snowbound. Where to stay 
The swishest hotels in Ulan Baatar are the Shangri-La ( shangri-la.com/ulaanbaatar ) and the Kempinski Khan Palace ( kempinski.com/en/ulaanbaatar/hotel-khan-palace ). Follow Telegraph Travel
